Im finding it hard to find the right amount of testing when I
create my tests.

Example:
I have a http server that receives http requests. These request is
in the server split into different actions. The actions can be
"login" or "logoff" etc.

Actions are seperate classes, which has been tested for "most" possible
errors and possibilities. I have one unit testcase for each action.


Now im sitting and doing some HTTP-Unit testing of the whole http server,
trying to login, logoff, etc. I start the server and connect to it as a
real HTTP client, to test the functionality.

But somehow I started to create similar tests for each action that Ive
already tested (testing the same problems that I did on the action level),
which means Im sitting with ALOT of testcases that looks the same but are
invoked from different levels. (the action itself is one level, the
server is on a higher level)


What is the "right" amount of testing, is it best to do the same test but
on different levels in order to make sure that NO strange behaviour is
discovered or should I just test the whole flow?

More tests = better software? ;)
